fields.descriptive_line: Thornhill, James; design for the upper hall at Greenwich: George I receiving a sceptre from Providence, surrounded by the royal family and allegorical figures. In the foreground is the artist himself, holding palette and brushes. c.1717
fields.title: Design for the upper hall at Greenwich: George I receiving a sceptre from Providence, surrounded by the royal family and allegorical figures. In the foreground is the artist himself, holding palette and brushes
fields.materials_techniques: Pen and ink and wash over preliminary pencil and incised lines
fields.marks:
Inscribed with a scale divided into 32 parts and, in brown ink:
    Sec: Vinnol: div in partes 32 epv [?] vbl: mod:
with traces of pencil inscriptions and on the back of the mount:
Design for the Tribune at Greenwich/ Sir James Thornhill EE-1803
in a later hand.
fields.bibliography:
The finished painting was described by Sir James Thornhill as follows: Angels, Cupids, &c. Drawing the Curtain, and opening the scene, where his Majesty is sitting, and leaning on a Terrestrial Globe, as PROVIDENCE descends, and puts the Scepter into his Hands. On his right-hand is PRUDENCE, represented by the PRINCESS OF WALES, also CONCORD with the Fasces by the Queen of Prussia. Over the King's Head is ASTREA with her Ballance returning to the Earth, which is represented by CYBELE or the Princess SOPHIE. Under ASTREA are little cupids with this Motto: JAM REDIT ET VIRGO, &c. Alluding to JUSTICE, and the Golden Age restored, who is on her Right-hand pouring forth Riches, &c., froma Cornucopia. Over all is a Figure holding a PYRAMID, which signifies Stability, or the Glory of Princes. On his Majesty's knee leans Prince FREDERICK, by him his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, on whose Left-hand is a figure representing NAVAL VICTORY, with a Trident, Rostral Crown, Palm and Laurel, holding a vast SCROLL, on which are recorded several of the Gallant ENGLISH ACTIONS at Sea. PEACE and PLENTY are offering at his Majesty's Feet: the little GENII of PAINTING, POETRY and MUSICK, represented by the Three young Princesses: round the Cornucopia are Prince William and his other Sisters playing with a Dove, showing Love and Harmony in this illustrious Family (From "An Explanation of the Painting in the Royal Hospital at Greenwich" by Sir James Thornhill)
Mayhew, Pl/7
fields.credit: From the Collection of Lord Northwick
fields.history_note:
The finished painting was described by Sir James Thornhill as follows: Angels, Cupids, &c. Drawing the Curtain, and opening the scene, where his Majesty is sitting, and leaning on a Terrestrial Globe, as PROVIDENCE descends, and puts the Scepter into his Hands. On his right-hand is PRUDENCE, represented by the PRINCESS OF WALES, also CONCORD with the Fasces by the Queen of Prussia. Over the King's Head is ASTREA with her Ballance returning to the Earth, which is represented by CYBELE or the Princess SOPHIE. Under ASTREA are little cupids with this Motto:

JAM REDIT ET VIRGO, &c.

Alluding to JUSTICE, and the Golden Age restored, who is on her Right-hand pouring forth Riches, &c., froma Cornucopia. Over all is a Figure holding a PYRAMID, which signifies Stability, or the Glory of Princes. On his Majesty's knee leans Prince FREDERICK, by him his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, on whose Left-hand is a figure representing NAVAL VICTORY, with a Trident, Rostral Crown, Palm and Laurel, holding a vast SCROLL, on which are recorded several of the Gallant ENGLISH ACTIONS at Sea. PEACE and PLENTY are offering at his Majesty's Feet: the little GENII of PAINTING, POETRY and MUSICK, represented by the Three young Princesses: round the Cornucopia are Prince William and his other Sisters playing with a Dove, showing Love and Harmony in this illustrious Family
(From "An Explanation of the Painting in the Royal Hospital at Greenwich" by Sir James Thornhill)

Literature: E. de N. Mayhew, 'Sketches by Thornhill in the Victoria and Albert Museum', 1967. Pl/7

Exhibitions: marble Hill House, 'English Baroque Sketches', 1974, no. 27.
